title: This is why I say Riot has a ranged biased to an unavoidable degree.
body:
Hey guys it appears people are complaining about melee being useless again, what should we do?

Oh I have an idea, how about a champion with a 20% HP nuke that can dash away on every auto attack!... what?

Oh also Sion has lower armor than Lucian. You know, because Sion is hard to kill... for range, sometimes, I guess.

replies.body: "Mobility creep is a real problem in this game!" *releases Kalista*
The real issue is who its a problem for. Mobility creep isn't a problem for mobile champs like kalista. They need to give strengths for unmobile champs, not remove mobility IMO.

Exactly.  Long time players will shake thier fists at Lee Sin and Leblanc for embodying the worst in mobility creep, but in reality Ashe and Varus are just bottom-tier.  They don't have anywhere near enough utility to justify their lack of escapes.  Before you drop the downvote hammer, let me show examples from Smite.  Smite never had "mobility creep" per say, because all their champs came packaged with huge amounts of mobility.  And if they didn't, they have a fuckton of utility to back it up (Critemis just chunking gods and locking them down effortlessly, Nox an ObNoxIous anti-caster, Sylvanus being broken, etc.)  What about Ashe?  The only hard CC she has is her Ultimate when Morgana gets it on her Q that lasts equally as long.  Varus?  Same boat.

So instead of telling Riot to do something about mobility creep, rework the dashing system so that the guys with no hard CC can still keep LeBlanc from double dashing effectively the entire game.

What would really interest me with Kalista is exactly how much extra ground her passive covers, compared to shooting and moving in between. Despite that passive, she has low MS (325), and can't cancel her animations, either.

Dodging certain skillshots could really be a pain in the ass with her.

From what I can tell, mid-late game she actually loses DPS (compared to other ADCs) due to her auto wind-up and the animation time of the dash (and of course depending on your mechanics). It's looking to me like she's actually worse at kiting for short periods of time compared to other ADCs with a dash, just due to the downtime she has inbetween her autos and the comparatively shorter ranged dash (and no self peel or juking mechanics of Vayne), but if you don't catch her in the beginning, it's going to be pretty tough to get on her afterwards.

I could be completely wrong though :P

Lee's moveset will always make him good, no matter how much he's nerfed. As long as his Q does decent damage and the rest of his moves move him around the map and displace enemies, that's all Lee needs.

> OK, this is true, but it needs expanding. Any champion that begins to crowd out other picks is complained about, and they eventually get nerfed. Except Lee Sin, but he is melee so you will conveniently ignore that.

Not really ignoring, Riot already mentioned that they would work on him to make sure he doesn't overpower in S5. He has a hard kit to balance, much like Lucian has been giving them trouble.

To beat Yasuo you had to play a near perfect game. However, to win as Yasuo, you could make several mistakes, and still come out on top. I haven't played him enough to know about the nerfs in great detail, but beforehand, any competent player could go legendary with ease as Yasuo.

Regardless, melee champions are actually quite strong. A ranged AA distance is very insignificant, especially if you consider the leaps, dashes, and blinks available to most melee champions. Furthermore, it is often difficult to be ranged and still build tank, so most ranged champions get diced fairly easily.

The only real difficult part about melee vs. ranged is perhaps the laning phase. In the end, the equalizer (the jungle) is always around to help if you can't CS at all.
Release Yasuo had some pretty BS numbers on his shield and his damage was just wayyyy too high.

Yasuo had his own problems and the issue I find is that most of the Melee champs that are usually good are assassins or burst you before you can do anything. Yi/Yas/Fiora are the ones that come to mind that really irritate me personally. They have an underlying factor that I think needs to be toned back, but not removed since I feel like this is everyone's reaction and Riots decision instead of tweaking. 

I'm tired of riot gutting champs anyway. I feel like there are small tweaks and number reworks. Looking at Yas again I don't think they targeted the right area for him. I think they should have hit his passive instead of his base stats that they did. His survivability was never the problem imo, but his straight damage early and having to only get 1 item before he starts to spike. This coupled with a great late game caused for a champion that is fun to play, but beyond overpowered. Yet instead of targeting his late game or making his early game worse they destroyed his survivability to the point of his Win rate dying. I think if they made his passive scale at lvls 6, 11, and 16 so that his passive now is the lvl 16 scale would make yasuo better as an overall champ. 

Now that i got my minor rant out I really think the problem is also the fact that for some of the stronger melee champs if they get a small edge they can do what they want. They can zone better than most Ranged champs. I'm looking mainly at snowballing champs here. So yea you could say that is a problem or you could focus on this a little bit and use this to "balance melee" champs.
While in reality, release Yasuo was balanced? Do you self-medicate by any chance?

 >an 80% slow into a stun into a slow field +knock up into an 80% slow.

Braum and any form of CC really hurts nongap closers so its not really fair to compare it to only melee champs. Any champion ranged or melee with a gap closer doesn't care as much about these forms of CC. If you didn't have this there would be much to combat Melee champs late game. Early game they get out harassed pretty easy, but late game or the moment they can close the gap through gap closers or simply walking up to them there is no getting them off.

Melees aren't useless, just... Different. They simply have very different play styles from ranged.  Melee champs have a harder time of deciding when to attack than ranged, simply because of how they are more exposed to attacks while doing so. This requires more difficult choices to be made in trading damage. Melees are more reliant on moments of power, and their enemy's moments of weakness.

Not to mention that I'm pretty sure if ranged champions were entirely superior, you wouldn't have seen any melees at Worlds...

If you look at the win rate, it seems majority of all the champs with the highest win rates are melee champs. 

http://oce.op.gg/statistics/champion/

The game is almost like paper sissors rock, some melee champs get owned by various ranged champs, then others obliterate them. Every champ has its awesome match ups, even matchups and horrible match ups where you wish you could nerf the other champ completely. So far to me it seems that most champs are reasonably balanced and have a particular counter that devistates them.

I think that the bigger issue is that some champs get played upto 44% of all ranked game's and other get picked less than 1%, therefore some champs never get to be considered "OP" because they very rarely get matched against their "counter part"... at least thats the way it seems in the OCE ranked game stats.

I purposely looked at all the champions that have been picked the most and Identified the best "counter" that is the least played. Practiced them like crazy and it seems to have helped alot in my win rate. The lower the pick rate, the less likely the player is to have faced them frequently enough to figure out all of their moves and it gives you a better chance at winning.

The main champ I use no is Heimerdinger (before everyone says OMG thats a noob champ) it actually takes a hell of a lot of skill to play him knowing which way to set your towers up & the higher the MMR of your opponents the trickier and smarter you need to play, but the good thing about him is that you can play him in almost every spot & he only has a 1.4% pick rate... people arent used to facing him & dont know how to beat him until its too late & you already have the gold advantage.

Making good summoner spells is the real solution. Dawngate had a great setup for this. 

They had a spell that gave 30% MS for 6s and CC(excluding suppression) immunity for 3s to melee and 1.5s to ranged. 

This made so many melee's viable in that game. 
Obviously it'd be OP on many champions. But it's not rare for Riot to change something and have to balance a few champions around that change. 
But the fact is that it would make many champions who need this type of spell viable. Even ranged ones who would have half the duration of immunity. 
It's not like Cleanse is in a great spot right now either. 

Sure that game had it's own version of Flash as well. But it was never really mandatory on most champions. It was still a strong pick. Then again the game had little resource costs. So a champion with mobility really wasn't punished for using it like you would be in League. Another lesson Riot could learn here as well. I feel most Melee's would be in a far greater spot without some of their mana costs. They can be re-balanced around this. Gaining other options such as Rage or even something new. 
Top of that this would also made a few more options in the jungle. Being able to spam an ability on a stationary mob isn't the same as harassing an opponent. It can be balanced to work.

I'm pretty rusty with DotA stats now but:

20% chance to reduce 25 damage on an item that can be bought before creeps spawn.

Ranged attacks do 40 damage at most early game. 

Two spell casts at level 3 causes you to be OOM for most heroes, so early harass is much harder to achieve - this effect is increased by the fact that healing consumables aren't especially expensive but very effective at keeping someone in lane, at least for pre-level-6 laning. 

Melee carries have damage-mitigation mechanisms (see spectre passively taking 16% less damage from all sources)

Melee actually has statistical advantage compared to Ranged (i.e. can have 400 health more than Ranged when max level, more base damage, more attackspeed, more base armor)

Turn rate making Ranged Orbwalking when moving backwards inefficient

Gold in DotA being a precious resource, and spending it on Force Staff and Blink Dagger has equally powerful opportunity costs
